body: This label `for` attribute uses the form `id` but it should be the input id, in this case it looks like you are looking for `message`

body:
The `form` attribute can be omitted, without it the input/textarea is associated with the nearest parent form. In this case it would be `usrform`

Sometimes is good to be "explicit" (and I personally prefer it) but in this case I have never seen this `form` attribute in the wild, so I would expect people using it when it is really needed.

For example here I thought "why is this form attribute used here" ? and spend a few extra minutes reviewing this line of code

@@ -0,0 +1,91 @@ + + + + + Contact us + + + + + +
+ + + +
+
+
body:
I this the only form that you have in the entire site?
If not, using a general name like "form" can cause confusion because there are other "forms"

You can be a little more specific here with `contact-form`

body:
try to avoid abusing the `section` element. 

They aren't as useful as we may think, read more [here](https://www.internetingishard.com/html-and-css/semantic-html/#sections)

The most important part is that each section requires a heading or it will mess the document outline, so as a rule of thumb, if you don't have a heading for a section; just use a `div`

body:
Out of the scope but:
`input` without a label isn't accessible, people using accessibility software cannot know what this field is for. 
In this case, that you have an input field without a label on the design, you can use the plan B: use the `aria-label` attribute to add a label to the field. [Read more here](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Accessibility/ARIA/ARIA_Techniques/Using_the_aria-label_attribute)

In this case it would be something like: `aria-label="Email"`.

body:
These "loader" states could have been a div and a bit of CSS. A div and a little of CSS have almost no effect on the assets/files that the user has to download to see the site. Here it is downloading an extra 2 files

However, premature optimization is the root of all evil and this probably don't have an noticeable effect on the user experience so if it works for you, it works for me

body:
I would use an h2 here instead of h1.
The truth is that the main effect of the headings is to write a correct document outline and `sections` have no effect on that.

So in this whole document, which is the main heading? and which is the secundary headings?

Try to set the headings in a whole document perspective instead of at the component level

body:
In my opinion, these cannot be considered "headings"
Remember that a heading is not "big fonts" but have a semantic meaning, 
they introduce a piece of text or open a new section on the document.
A good way to think about it is: would I put this info as a heading in a WORD document?
Sorry if you haven't used WORD and that analogy doesn't work for you 🙏
